title: How Systems Come Into Existence: The Dialectic of History
subtitle: Dialectics is a way of thinking that focuses on how opposing forces interact, with each side depending on the other while also challenging it. — Bertell Ollman, Dance of the Dialectic (2003)
body:
Many people assume systems (such as those in the U.S.) originate and evolve because a group of thinkers designed them and then reshaped them according to their plans. Others think rich elites design and modify them to rig the rules in their favor. Still others imagine history as steady, linear progress, where ideas emerge and improve through the accumulation of knowledge, evidence, and better policies. Yet history rarely moves so neatly. In reality, change is driven by tension and conflict between competing ideas. Old ideas collide with new realities, systems buckle under the pressure of their own assumptions, and from that friction something new takes shape. This pattern of transformation is what philosophers call the dialectic process.

Think about how communism collided with early industrial-capitalism to produce welfare capitalism due to the tensions created by the exploitative working conditions of the early industrial capitalism, class inequality and labor alienation. Nobody deliberately designed this welfare capitalism from the outset, but it emerged from a struggle between two diametrically opposite ideologies.

What Is a Dialectic?

The dialectic process describes how an existing idea, system, or social order generates its own opposition as contradictions, tensions, and conflicts emerge. Those contradictions create counter-movements that challenge the dominant order, and the struggle between the two produces a new arrangement that absorbs elements of both. In medieval Europe, for example, the Catholic Church’s central authority produced tensions through corruption and coercion, which helped generate reform movements that reshaped Christianity and the political order.

In its simplest form, it is often summarized as:

  • Thesis: a dominant idea, worldview, or institutional arrangement

  • Antithesis: a counter-force that exposes contradictions within the thesis

  • Synthesis: a new formation that resolves the tension while preserving elements of both

This is akin to two gushing streams of water colliding to produce a stable stream (a synthesis), and the process continues.

Share

This is not a fixed formula, but a way to see change instead of stability. Over time, the synthesis itself becomes a new thesis, giving rise to fresh contradictions (an antithesis), and the whole process repeats as history advances.

Dialectic movement of history

Where the Dialectic Comes From

The dialectic, although found in many ancient works, is most famously associated with the philosopher Friedrich Hegel. Hegel argued that history is the unfolding of reason through contradictions. For Hegel, ideas are not static truths but living processes. Every concept contains internal tensions that push it beyond itself. Freedom, authority, morality, and even self-consciousness in a society develop through struggle, not harmony.

Later, Karl Marx transformed this framework by grounding it in material conditions rather than pure ideas. Where Hegel saw the dialectic unfolding in consciousness, Marx located it in economic relations and class conflict. Capitalism, in Marx’s view, generates immense productivity while simultaneously producing inequality and alienation. These contradictions intensify tensions within the existing mode of production and, through class struggle, drive a transition to a new mode of production, which Marx believed could unfold through successive historical stages and ultimately culminate in a communist world order.

Despite their differences, both thinkers shared a crucial insight: contradiction is not a flaw in a system; it is the engine of its evolution.

Dialectics in Real-World Systems

Dialectical processes are not confined to philosophy. They are visible across economics, politics, and social life.

An interesting example comes from the political influence of AIPAC in U.S. politics, which can be understood as a dominant thesis that institutionalizes unconditional support for Israel. However, over time, this dominance has generated internal contradictions within U.S. political circles, particularly around concerns about human rights violations and the marginalization of the Palestinian population. These tensions have given rise to an emerging antithesis within the liberal left that challenges donor-driven influence and demands moral consistency. It has also generated an antithesis on the conservative right. Any synthesis is unlikely to abolish lobbying altogether in the near term, but may instead recalibrate the boundaries of U.S. unconditional support for Israel.

In economics, consider the recurring tension between market freedom and regulation. Unregulated markets often produce growth and innovation, but they also generate instability and inequality. Regulation emerges as an antithesis, correcting excesses but sometimes stifling dynamism. The modern mixed economy is a synthesis, never final, always contested.

In politics, the tension between state authority and civil society is deeply dialectical. Too much state power leads to despotism; too little leads to fragmentation. Stability emerges only when both sides remain strong and constrained by each other. This balance is not permanent. It must be continually renegotiated.

Why Dialectical Thinking Matters Today

Dialectical thinking pushes us to critique existing worldviews with the expectation of refinement rather than total replacement. If people aim for total replacement, they set themselves up for disappointment because total replacement in a dialectical struggle is rare.

In addition, the resulting synthesis is shaped by the relative strength of the thesis and the antithesis. If the thesis is much more powerful than the antithesis, the status quo will change only slightly. However, if the system is to be modified in a major way (producing a markedly different status quo), the antithesis must be strong. This means that people who intend to change a system in a meaningful way (that is, to generate a new synthesis) need to be strongly empowered.

Share

Dialectical thinking also offers an antidote to two common intellectual failures.

The first is utopianism. This is the belief that a single correct idea, once implemented, will dissolve conflict. Utopian thinking ignores the fact that every solution generates new contradictions. Thinkers committed to a worldview must be able to integrate real-world constraints into their moral and ontological framework if they want their ideals to produce meaningful change.

The second is fatalism. This is the belief that systems and power structures are preordained (through fate) and it is hopeless to make a change. Fatalism overlooks the internal stresses that eventually force transformation.

Conclusion

The dialectic process reminds us that history is not a straight line and progress is not a clean story. Change emerges through tension, contradiction, and negotiation. Ideas do not simply replace one another; they collide, merge, and mutate.

Dialectics helps us think about what is possible. It trains us to focus on processes, not fixed positions. In an age of polarization and shallow certainty, this kind of thinking is highly necessary.
